The patient's presentation of fever, nasal congestion and convulsions suggests a severe allergic response. However, based on the system's description, the patient seems to have an infection possibly caused by a virus (as indicated by "Influenza A virus Flu-AV Negative (-)").

The system is experiencing symptoms consistent with an upper respiratory tract infection, which may be caused by either Influenza A virus or Parainfluenza virus Type I. The negative results of the anti-enterovirus and anti-coxsackievirus tests suggest that these are less likely to be the cause. Given the system's symptoms (coughing, dry cough, rashes on the body, itching throat), a respiratory tract infection is more probable.

In this case, the system should analyze and compare the symptoms provided in the patient's report to known diseases and determine which disease is most likely: "Epidemic influenza", "Hand, foot, and mouth disease" (also known as Hand-Foot-and-Mouth Disease), or "Herpangina".
